properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major snowfall is expected Saturday evening and Sunday. Total snowfall amounts will reach 15 to 20 centimetres. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant precipitation expected beginning tonight and persisting into Sunday for some areas. Total snowfall: 15-35 cm for Northern New Brunswick. Total rainfall: Near 30 mm for areas near the Fundy coast. Locations: New Brunswick. Time span: Tonight through to Sunday morning. Remarks: Snow and ice pellets are expected to spread across northern New Brunswick and rain across southern New Brunswick tonight. Snow, freezing rain or ice pellets are expected for the remaining areas of the province tonight, with a change over to rain possible. Snowfall warnings are in effect over northeastern parts of the province while rainfall warnings are in effect for some southern areas. Conditions across the province will begin to improve on Sunday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-17T00:10:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-16T08:11:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1410902442.2021

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are expected by tonight. Snow, heavy at times, will continue near noon today before tapering to periods of snow this afternoon. The periods of snow will continue tonight before coming to an end by early Sunday morning. Hazardous winter driving conditions are expected. Motorists should change travel plans accordingly. This snowstorm is due to a strong low pressure system tracking northeastward across coastal portions of New England. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-17T07:32:34-00:00

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels and large waves are expected near the coast on 2021/01/17. An intense low pressure system from the Eastern American seaboard will give strong winds over the areas listed below. The combination of these winds and the current run of mid-amplitude tidal ranges may produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast near the following localities on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Forillon Park - Gaspé - Percé: 2021-01-17, from 02:30 AM to 06:30 AM. New-Carlisle - Chandler: 2021-01-17, from 03:00 AM to 07:00 AM. Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier: 2021-01-17, from 02:30 AM to 06:30 AM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-17T01:31:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-16T09:32:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0999401347.2021
Area: Chandler area, New Carlisle - Port-Daniel area, Forillon National Park - Gaspé area, Percé area, Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterlies up to 90 km/h, except up to 100 km/h for Cape Breton Island Locations: The Atlantic coast of mainland Nova Scotia for Halifax and east, and Cape Breton Island Time span: Overnight into Sunday morning. Remarks: An intensifying low pressure system approaching from New England will give increasingly strong southeasterly winds tonight into Sunday, with gusts reaching 90 to 100 km/h. There is also a Les Suetes wind warning in effect for Cape Breton Island from Margaree Harbour to Bay St. Lawrence, as well as rainfall warnings for the Atlantic coast of mainland Nova Scotia and much of Cape Breton Island. ### Gusty winds can damage soft shelters, tents and awnings at outdoor events. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-17T06:56:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-16T14:57:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0754355138.2021

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 25 to 30 cm is expected. Locations: northeastern New Brunswick. Time span: Tonight through Sunday afternoon. Remarks: Areas of northern New Brunswick will likely see 15 to 25 cm of snow and ice pellets with this system. However, the highest snowfall accumulations will occur over parts of northeastern New Brunswick where amounts of up to 35 cm are possible by Sunday evening. Gusty easterly winds will develop overnight and give blowing snow over exposed areas. Additionally, higher than normal water levels are expected along the coast near high tide Sunday evening. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-17T06:37:31-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High Storm Surge levels and large waves are expected to impact the coast. Maximum water levels: near 1 metre above high astronomical tide. Maximum wave heights: 4 to 6 metres. Locations: Iles de la Madeleine, mainly east facing shorelines. Time span: from 11:00 a.m. AST on Sunday to 3:00 p.m. AST Sunday. High tide: about 1:00 pm AST on Sunday. Remarks: An intensifying low pressure system moving into the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Sunday will give a combination of storm surge and rough and pounding waves to produce some coastal flooding along east facing shorelines of the Islands. ### High waves combined with the surge may cause damage along the coast. Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-17T06:57:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-16T14:58:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2793954771.2021
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: Southeasterlies up to 100 km/h. Time span: Overnight tonight until Sunday near noon. Remarks: An intensifying low pressure system approaching from New England will give increasingly strong southeasterly winds tonight into Sunday. A storm surge warning is also in effect for the Islands. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds with damaging wind gusts are expected or occurring. Maximum Les Suetes gusts: 100 km/h near midnight increasing to near 180 km/h Sunday morning. Time span: This evening until midday Sunday. Remarks: Southeast winds will begin gusting to near 100 km/h near midnight tonight then will increase to near 150 km/h near dawn on Sunday, The gusts are forecast to further increase to near 180 km/h Sunday morning before diminishing near midday. ### Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-17T06:48:30-00:00

Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. Total rainfall: 30 to 50 mm, with locally higher amounts. Locations: the Atlantic Coast of mainland Nova Scotia, and most of Cape Breton Island. Time span: This evening until Sunday morning. Remarks: Rain, at times heavy, will begin this evening and will be accompanied by strong southeast winds. The heaviest rain is expected later in the evening and into the overnight hours before tapering to scattered showers Sunday morning. Wind warnings are also in effect for eastern Mainland Nova Scotia and Cape Breton Island. In addition a Les Suetes Wind Warning is in effect in Cape Breton from Margaree Harbour to Bay St. Lawrence. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: High Water Level Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High water levels and large waves are forecast for Sunday. Locations: Iles de la Madeleine, especially eastern facing shorelines. Maximum water levels: exceeding high astronomical tide. Maximum wave heights: 4 to 6 metres. High tide: near high tide near noon Sunday. Remarks: Strong easterly winds, large waves and high water levels may cause damage to coastal infrastructure and coastal erosion, especially to east facing coastlines of Iles-de-la-Madeleine. ### Coastal flooding is possible, especially during high tide. Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. High water level warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
Expires: 2021-01-17T05:48:38-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dangerous wind gusts are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly gusting to 100 km/h overnight tonight and gusting to 140 km/h on Sunday. Locations: the Wreckhouse area. Time span: overnight tonight until Sunday afternoon. Remarks: Winds should reach their peak near noon on Sunday and then subside in the afternoon. ### Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at risk of being overturned. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-17T06:09:12-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Another strong frontal system is expected to move across Haida Gwaii this morning. Winds are expected to increase to southeast 90 gusting to 110 km/h this morning. The winds will ease to below warning criteria by early this afternoon, but will remain gusty out of the southwest. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-16T23:59:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-16T13:02:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1453046185.2021
Area: Haida Gwaii
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterlies up to 90 km/h. Time span: Early Sunday morning. Remarks: An intensifying low pressure system approaching from New England will give increasingly strong southeasterly winds tonight into Sunday, with gusts reaching 90 km/h early Sunday morning, before diminishing near noon. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
